The "Campaign Details" and "Key Metrics Summary" sections are located together at the **bottom of the under the main applications window**, spanning its full width.

*   **Side-by-Side Layout:** They are arranged horizontally next to each other:
    *   The **"Campaign Details"** section is on the **bottom-left**.
    *   The **"Key Metrics Summary"** section is on the **bottom-right**.
    *   The "Key Metrics Summary" section contains an **"Export XLSX"** button at its very bottom right corner, which represents one of the final actions a user can take in this workflow.
### **"Campaign Details" Section**

This section should be laid out in two columns.

**Left Column:**
*   **Campaign Name:** (Displays the name of the campaign selected in "My Campaigns"/the standard campaigns table)
*   **Financed Amount:**
*   **Subsidy utilized (THB):**
*   **Dealer Commissions Paid (THB):**
*   **IDC - Free Insurance (THB):**

**Right Column:**
*   **Term (months):**
*   **Subsidy budget (THB):**
*   **Subsidy remaining (THB):**
*   **IDCs - Others (THB):**
*   **IDC - Free MBSP (THB):**

### **"Key Metrics Summary" Section**

This section should also be laid out in two columns.

**Left Column:**
*   **Monthly Installment:**
*   **Effective Rate:**
*   **Acquisition RoRAC:**
*   **IDC - Dealer Comm/other dealer benefits.:**

**Right Column:**
*   **Nominal Customer Rate:**
*   **Financed amount:**
*   **IDC Total:**
*   **IDC - Other:**
Furthermore, importantly, there is the fold out of the detailed acquistion rorac calculation breakdown foldout, that the user can click to see the details of how this was calculated. refer to the exact implementation and layout in the go app for implementing this.

function.name: invoke_subagent
function.description:
<summary>Delegate tasks to specialized subagents.

Task descriptions should be clear and specific and include any information relevant to the task. The delegated
agent will only have the context you provide before it starts working on the task.

The following subagents are available:
 - Name: doc-agent | Description: Agent to continously update the project implementation actuals, based on observed actual code, in one structured document</summary>
<returns>
<description>A string containing the summarized result from the subagent.</description>
</returns>

subagent_name.description: The name of the subagent to delegate the task to.

task_description.description: A description of the task to delegate.

task_name.description:
A short name for the task (<= 5 words) to uniquely identify it. Names should be related
to the task being solved.

function.name: open_files
function.description: Open one or more files in the workspace. Supports text, image, and PDF documents.

file_paths.description: A list of file paths to open.

function.name: create_file
function.description: Create a file in the workspace.

initial_content.description: The initial content to write to the file.

overwrite.description: Whether to overwrite the file if it already exists.

function.name: delete_file
function.description: Delete a file from the workspace.

function.name: move_file
function.description: Move or rename a file in the workspace.

file_path.description: The path of the file to move.

new_path.description: The new path for the file.

function.name: expand_code_chunks
function.description:
Expand line ranges or code chunks within a file and return the expanded content.

Code can be expanded by specifying line ranges or by searching for code symbols in the code, separating levels of
hierarchy with slashes.

Example patterns:
- "MyClass": Selects the class definition and any references to MyClass.
- "my_function": Selects the function definition and any uses of my_function.
- "def my_function": Selects only the function definition for my_function.
- "MyClass/my_method": Selects the method my_method within MyClass using slash separator.

file_path.description: The path of the file in which to select code.

patterns.description:
A list of string patterns to search for and expand in the content of the file. Examples are function
names, class names, variable names, etc.

line_ranges.description:
A list of tuples representing the start and end of the line ranges to expand. Note that line ranges
should use python-style indices (zero-based, non-inclusive end line). A entire file can be expanded using
[[0, -1]].

function.name: find_and_replace_code
function.description: Find and replace code in a file.

file_path.description: The path of the file in which to find and replace code.

find.description:
The code snippet to find. Use string literals when including any special
characters that you want included literally.

replace.description:
The code snippet to replace with. Use string literals when including any
special characters that you want included literally.

function.name: grep
function.description:
Search for a pattern in the content or file paths of all files in the workspace.

This function can be used in three distinct modes: content search, path search, and path-filtered content search.
1. Content Search: If only content_pattern is provided, it searches for the pattern in the content of all files.
2. Path Search: If only path_pattern is provided, it searches for the pattern in the file paths.
3. Path-Filtered Content Search: If both content_pattern and path_pattern are provided, it first filters the files
by the path pattern and then searches for the content pattern in the filtered files.

Example patterns:
- content_pattern = "class Myclass": Finds the class definition for Myclass in all files.
- path_pattern = "*/subdir/to/*.py": Finds all Python files in the specified subdirectory.
- content_pattern = "class Myclass" and path_pattern = "*/subdir/to/*.py": Finds the class definition for
Myclass in all Python files in the specified subdirectory. Note that path_pattern is a glob pattern, and
content_pattern is regex.

content_pattern.description:
The regex pattern to search for in the file contents. This is a regular expression, so ensure
to escape any special characters if needed.

path_glob.description:
The glob pattern to search for in the file paths. Note that the path_pattern glob should match
the full path, not just parts of it. For example, "subdir/*.py" will not match "dir/subdir/file.py", but
"*/subdir/*.py" will match it.

function.name: expand_folder
function.description: Expand a folder in the workspace.

folder_path.description: The path of the folder to expand.

function.name: powershell
function.description:
Execute a PowerShell command on the workspace.

Commands are run in the workspace root directory. Typically used to reproduce bugs or verify features are
working as expected. Avoid making calls that will result in very large outputs, as they may be truncated.

Interactive commands should be used sparingly and should be run in the background with `background=True` to avoid
blocking.

Example commands:
- `git log --oneline -n 50`: Show the git log for the last 50 commits.
- `powershell minimal_reproducible_example_script.ps1`: Run a PowerShell script in the workspace.
- `Start-Job { Get-Process }`: Start a background PowerShell job.

command.description:
The command to execute. Can also be an integer PID, in which case the running logs from that command
will be returned (excluding any logs that have been previously retrieved). For interactive processes, you
can send input by using a string in the format: "PID:input", where input is what to send to stdin.

background.description: If True, run the command in the background. Background commands can be monitored using the PID.

function.name: mcp__mcp_gopls__get_tool_schema
function.description:
<summary>Get the input schema for a specific tool from the mcp-gopls toolset.

Available tools are:
- FindImplementers(column, file, line)
- FindReferences(column, file, includeDeclaration, line)
- FormatCode(file)
- GetDiagnostics(file)
- GoToDefinition(column, file, line)
- Hover(column, file, line)
- ListDocumentSymbols(file)
- OrganizeImports(file)
- RenameSymbol(column, file, line, newName)
- SearchSymbol(query)</summary>
<returns>
<description>The input schema for the specified tool.</description>
</returns>

tool_name.description: The name of the tool to get the schema for.
